This prompts the question as whether these lines are distinct, i.e. they have no point in common, or if they are equal. We offer two approaches to answer this question.
Approach 1 We pick a random solution of one equation and check if it is also a solution of the other. If yes, the two parallel lines are equal. If not, they are distinct.
A solution of the first equation is (-1,-1) . We see immediately that this is also a solution of the second equation. Therefore the two lines are equal.

So \Vect{a}_2 = \tfrac{4}{3} \Vect{a}_1 , implying that the two lines are equal.
Either way, we conclude that the collection of pairs (x,y) solving both equations simultaneously, is the same as the collection of pairs which solve just one the equations.

Why are these vectors not parallel?
Suppose \Vect{a}_1 were parallel to \Vect{a}_2 . Then we would have \Vect{a}_1 = t\cdot \Vect{a}_2 for some number t . Comparing the first three coordinates of these vectors requires t=-2 . But comparing the fourth coordinates forces t=2\neq -2 . Therefore no such t exists. The two vectors are not parallel.
